ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan Penagos Zuluaga
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan is passionate about tropical forestry and was great to have in Panama. He is such a delightful, energetic and knowledgeable person to be around!
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan was a great organizer and wonderful support system for logistics, assignments, and knowledge, on our Panama field trip.
Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Very helpful in the field. Always accessible and friendly. Personable, which made me feel like I could ask any questions I wanted.

Instructor: Juan Carlos Penagos Zuluaga  Juan was a great TA and very helpful when we were on site in Panama and afterwards. My only recommendation is that we interact with him more before we leave, which I know was challenging this year as he left for Panama at the start of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course was really interesting and a great way to get on the ground experience with field work. My recommendation would be to tie the two projects together and somehow introduce past research topics before we go on site so we can do some background research beforehand, if possible. Also, more time in the city would be great!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The Panama trip was incredible! Great line-up of speakers and a good assortment of hikes and other activities. It was really busy and tiring at times, but overall I gained a lot from the experience

The best apsect of this course was the hands-on learning of tropical ecology in an actual tropical forest. You get an understanding of what you learned in class and be able then to see and understand the concepts hands-on.

The field trip was amazing - very well organized, covered all of the concepts in the course. The instructor clearly put a lot of time and effort into organizing the field trip and I felt I learned so much more than I could ever have from a text book.
Field Trip!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The classes before the field trip felt a bit like "filler" and didn't add too much. Some of the readings were really interesting, especially those about the Panama Canal, but I might have gotten more out of them if I'd read them after the trip.

The readings at the beginning of the course could have been more focused on the process of doing an experiment. Or more guiding questions while reading the articles could have helped us dissect the article better. I would have also welcomed a few lectures dedicated to tree/insect identification specific to BCI/Gamboa.
Classes before the field trip could be more helpful/useful with a lecture component instead of only discussion.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Refer to comments above.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course provides an excellent overview of general tropical (forest) ecology. It changed the way I view forests and forest processes and will be of use for me for future work in tropical agro-forestry and agro-ecology.
This was an interesting course which helped me gain field work experience.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took the first part of the course in the fall and was interested to see the concepts and research applied on the ground.
To gain a better understanding of how a tropical forest works.
To gain exposure to field work.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! Great field trip and I learned a lot. I think the rapid research projects were also a good activity that added to my learning experience, even though it was a bit of a time crunch to wrap up the presentations, data analyses and papers at the end of the semester.
Yes. I also acquired additional skills (such as tree identification).
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We had to work in two different groups and that made organizing meetings and getting work done difficult. Some people didn't want to meet up and others put minimal effort in the group projects.

The group work was a great part of the course. I saw it as a way to practice the skill of working together with different researchers towards co-publication. The group work was also a nice way to dig deeper into a topic.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! Especially if you haven't been in a tropical forest before or are considering doing research in the tropics. Lots of great exposure and interesting research in Panama that's worth checking out. Liza has a lot of background in the country and some ongoing research projects that add a lot to the course. And if Juan is the TA, that's a bit plus!
Take the spring and fall course. Bring long socks to the field.
Definitely do it if you want a field work experience in a great country, and stay afterwards to travel!
